body: @fatihbaltaci ah yes, this makes sense. The decision for the `multi_scale` size should be taken out of the dataloader, because now each GPU will be creating different random `img_size` batches. We'll get this fixed in the next day or two. In the meantime `multi_scale` still works with single GPU.
@fatihbaltaci updates in commit 056eed28332f91c5ca8d0e9a722726a436d9a695. Everything should work now.

@glenn-jocher same error appeared in **utils.py#build_targets**. Error:

Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "train.py", line 213, in <module>
    multi_scale=opt.multi_scale,
  File "train.py", line 127, in train
    target_list = build_targets(model, targets, pred)
  File "/home/yolov3/utils/utils.py", line 302, in build_targets
    t, a, gwh = targets[j], a[j], gwh[j]
RuntimeError: copy_if failed to synchronize: device-side assert triggered

Yes, a new error (the same one you see) is showing up now testing on GCP with 2 K80s. I'm not quite sure what's causing this new error. I tried removing the `j` indexing and it still occurs further on in the same function. Stackflow search recommends testing on CPU, which does not reproduce the error. 

So it seems at present `multi_scale` only works on CPU and single GPU. The intended functionality is to randomly rescale the training every 10 batches, starting from 608 at batch 0, which I believe is the darknet approach. On a single GPU you should see:

```
  Epoch       Batch        xy        wh      conf       cls     total  nTargets      time
   0/269     0/14657     0.287      4.17       139      3.26       147        45     0.651
   0/269     1/14657     0.281      3.89       139       3.3       146        77     0.588
   0/269     2/14657      0.28      3.98       139      3.31       146        57     0.548
   0/269     3/14657     0.282      3.88       139      3.32       146        44     0.569
   0/269     4/14657     0.284      4.03       139      3.32       146        41     0.585
   0/269     5/14657     0.281      3.92       139      3.32       146       104     0.577
   0/269     6/14657     0.282      3.79       139      3.32       146        79     0.578
   0/269     7/14657     0.284      3.74       139      3.32       146        44     0.573
   0/269     8/14657     0.282      3.74       139      3.31       146        64     0.567
   0/269     9/14657      0.28      3.73       139      3.31       146        70     0.576
multi_scale img_size = 576
   0/269    10/14657      0.28       3.7       139      3.31       146        72     0.511
   0/269    11/14657      0.28      3.66       139      3.31       146        80     0.518
   0/269    12/14657     0.277      3.85       139      3.31       146        28     0.522
...
```

@fatihbaltaci We found a bug in models.py that was recreating the grids every batch. Bug is fixed now, and as a plus `--multi-scale` with multiple GPUs also works now after the bug fix. We tested this with 2 P100s on GCP.
@glenn-jocher Yes, multi-gpu with multi-scale is working now. Thank's for your support.
@ahmedtalbi what branch? Use the master branch, there are no other branches supported.
